Key Terms, Tables, …

Ch 7 - Sampling Distribution:

WHY? The reason we select a sample is to collect data to answer a research question about a population
x̅: Point estimator of the population mean μ
s: Point estimator of the population s.d. σ
p̂̂: Point estimator of the popluation proportion p
Population proportion: A part of a population with a particular attribute, expressed as a fraction, decimal, or percentage of the whole population
Sample distribution of x̅: Probability distribution of all possible values of the sample mean
Sampling distribution of p̂: Probability distribution of all possible values of the sample proportion p̂
Probability distribution: Mathematical function that provides the probabilities of occurrence of different possible outcomes in an experiment
Exepected value of x̅: E(x̅) = μ (when the expected value of the point estimator equals the population parameter, we say the point estimator is unbiased)
Sample size of Sampling distribution:
   1\ When the population has a normal distribution, the sampling distribution of x̅ is normally distributed for any sample size
   2\ In most applications, the sampling distribution of x̅ can be approximated by a normal distribution whenever the sample size is 30 or more
   3\ In some cases where the population is highly skewed or outliers are present, sample size of 50 may be needed
   4\ The sampling distirbution of p̂ can be approximated by a normal distribution whenever the sample size is large enough to satisfy these two conditions np >= 5 and n(1-p) >= 5
Central Limit Theorem: If you have a population with mean μ and standard deviation σ and take sufficiently large random samples from the population with replacement, then the distribution of the sample means will be approximately normally distributed
Standard error (σx̅): Standard error of the mean
Standard error (σp̂): Standard error of the proportion

Ch 8 - Confidence Intervals:

Interval estimate: The purpose of an interval estimate is to provide information about how close the point estimate is to the value of the population parameter
Point estimate vs. Interval estimate: A point estimate is a single number that estimates the value of the population parameter, while an interval estimate includes a range of possible values which are likely to include the population parameter
Confidence interval: Answers the question, how confident are you that the population mean will fall within this interval (are you 90% confident? 95%? or 99%?)
Figures:
Interval Estimate
Confidence Interval
Summary - Interval Estimate Summary
Summary - Sample Size Summary

Ch 9 - Hypothesis testing:

Null hypothesis: The null hypothesis is a statement about a population parameter. It is assumed to be true unless we have evidence to the contrary. The alternative hypothesis is an assertion that holds if the null hypothesis is false. It’s not always the same as the assertion or verbal claim that led to the test. The null hypothesis must always contain the equal sign, if it does not, the claim is put in the alternative hypothesis and the opposite is put in the null hypothesis.
Alternative hypothesis: The alternative hypothesis is the research hypothesis, opposite of what is stated by the null hypothesis.
Type 1 error: When you reject H0, but H0 is true (innocent person is wrongly convicted)
Type 2 error: When you do not reject H0, but H0 is false (guilty person is acquitted)
Decision rule: The decision rule specifies the conclusion to be reached for a given outcome of the test. It helps us decide whether to reject H0 or fail to reject H0 for a hypothesis test.
p-value: A p-value is the exact level of significance associated with the calculated value of the test statistic. It is the most extreme critical value that the test statistic would be capable of exceeding. If p-value < alpha, reject H0 otherwise do not reject it.
signficance level: The significance level, also denoted as alpha or α, is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true.
Figures:
Table - Testing Hypothesis about a Population Mean, σ known
Table - Testing Hypothesis about a Population Mean, σ unknown
Table - Sample Test about a Population Proportion

Ch 12 - Chi Squre Tests

Uses of Chi Square Analysis:
  1\ Goodness of fit tests - A test to see whether a sample can be from a specified population
  2\ Independence test between 2 variables
  3\ Comparing proportions from two or more independent samples
Distribution type:
  1\ The chi-square distribution is from the same family as normal distributions
  2\ The chi-square distribution is a continuous curve and chi-square is always positive
Goodness of fit test:
  1\ Each element of the population is assigned to ONE and ONLY ONE of the classes and categories
  2\ On each trial of a multinomial experiment, ONE and ONLY ONE of the outcome occurs
  3\ Each trial is assumed to be INDEPENDENT

Ch13 - Simple Regression Analysis

Linear Regression Equation:ŷ = B0 + B1x
  b0 is the y intercept of the line
  b1 is the slope of the line
  ŷ is the estimated value of y for a given value of x
Coefficient of Determination:
 1/ Provides a measure of the goodness of fit for the estimated regression equation (i.e. does the independent variable explain the dependent variable well)
 2/ Expresses proportion of the variation in the dependent variable (y) that is explained by the regression line: ŷ = B0 + B1x
Coefficient of Correlation (R): Describes both the direction and the strength of the linear relationship between two variables
r = (sign of b1)√r^2

Questions

13 a (sample final) - why do they use a z instead of t?
Why do you consider the alternate hypothesis when testing a hypothesis? Why do you reject if p is less than alpha?
